translated: Sutra of the Names of the Thousand Buddhas of the Future Star Constellation Eon, also called Gathering the Great Merits of All Buddhas
The name of the translator is lost, now attached to the Liang Catalog
Those who cultivate goodness will attain blessings, while those who do evil will have misfortune as evidence. The principle is clear, but few believe and awaken to it.
Having been born together in this world of the five turbidities and evils, the five aggregates, afflictions, and three poisons are rampant, and the cycle of birth and death has no end.
In the past, when the Buddha was in the world, the number of people was as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, but now it has gradually declined, with not even one in ten thousand remaining.
Why is this so?
Those who do good are few, while those who do evil are many. After death, they fall into the three evil paths, becoming fish, insects, or animals, and no longer obtain a human body.
Therefore, the Lotus Sutra says:
The three evil paths are filled, and the heavenly and human beings are reduced.
The end of the eon is not far off, and the long decline is lamentable.

Therefore, the TathÄgata teaches according to the capacities of beings, encouraging kindness and goodness, not begrudging body and life, diligently practicing with vigor, one can attain liberation. The effort of bowing with the head to the ground can eliminate immeasurable eons of offenses. With offenses extinguished and blessings arising, one attains non-action.

In the future Star Constellation Eon, there will be a thousand Buddhas appearing in the world, with names like this. If people hear their names, single-mindedly pay homage, and are not afraid of making mistakes, they will surely attain nirvÄá¹‡a, forever leaving behind the sufferings of the three evil paths and birth and death. Abiding peacefully in kindness and patience, they will be endowed with much learning.

If one is able to uphold and recite this, then one will definitely encounter the thousand Buddhas, eradicate the grave offenses of birth and death accumulated over immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya eons, and attain the Buddhas' supernormal powers, samÄdhi, and unobstructed eloquence.

Those who practice in this way will quickly attain supreme, perfect enlightenment. (The Dunhuang version does not have the preceding prose section.)
